Fe-mediated enhancement of phenol selectivity in syringol hydrodeoxygenation over an in-situ-activated CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst Hongying Sha Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Conceptualization a Yuxuan Feng Validation a Jingbo Mao Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation a b ⁎ Hui Lv Validation a Jinxia Zhou Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Conceptualization a b ⁎ a College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University Dalian 116622 China College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian, 116622, China b Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals, Dalian 116622, China Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals Dalian 116622 China Dalian Key Laboratory of Green Manufacturing Technology for Fine Chemicals, Dalian, 116622, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University, Dalian 116622, China. College of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Dalian University Dalian 116622 China The hydrodeoxygenation of lignin-derived syringol to phenol faces challenges in selectively cleaving CAryl–O bonds while maintaining aromatic ring and a phenolic -OH group integrity. Herein, we developed a trimetallic CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst that achieves 100 % syringol conversion and 52.4 % phenol selectivity, surpassing bimetallic CoAg/SiO2 (42.2 mol%) and monometallic Co/SiO2 (7.6 mol%) catalysts. As promoters, Ag facilitates the low-temperature reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and further to metallic Co, while Fe prevents excessive reduction of CoO to metallic Co. Through the synergistic effects of Fe and Ag on Co, the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst undergoes in situ reduction under reaction conditions (1 MPa H2, 330 °C), forming a polycrystalline CoO-Co structure with abundant oxygen vacancy (Oᴠ) and Lewis acid sites. The CoO-Co-Ov active sites facilitate heterolytic H2 cleavage while preferentially adsorbing and activating oxygen-containing functional groups over the aromatic ring of syringol. This dual functionality selectively promotes CAryl–O bond dissociation while suppressing undesired ring hydrogenation, providing an effective catalyst design strategy for sustainable phenol production from biomass-derived syringol. Graphical Abstract Ag facilitates the reduction of Co3O4, while Fe prevents excessive reduction, collectively mediating the in-situ-activated CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst to achieve high phenol selectivity in syringol hydrodeoxygenation. Keywords CoFeAg trimetallic catalyst Polycrystalline CoO-Co Oxygen vacancy Syringol Hydrodeoxygenation Phenol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the advancement of human society, the depletion of fossil fuels and environmental pollution have become increasingly severe. Consequently, extensive research is being conducted on safe, sustainable, and renewable energy solutions. Biomass energy has emerged as an ideal alternative to fossil fuels due to its abundant reserves, wide distribution, environmental benefits, and net-zero carbon emissions [1]. Lignin, a major component of biomass, is rich in aromatic ring structures. Its derivatives, such as syringols and guaiacols, can be converted into bulk platform aromatic compounds, including phenols and benzene [2]. Phenol is an important organic chemical raw material and intermediate, widely used in polymers, pharmaceuticals, pesticides, dye synthesis, and other fields [3]. Producing phenol from renewable lignin resources will pave the way for economically sustainable synthesis routes for phenol. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) represents a promising approach for biomass refining. The key challenge in the HDO of lignin derivatives to phenol lies in developing efficient catalysts that exhibit high reactivity and good selectivity for CAr yl-O bond cleavage while preserving the aromatic rings from hydrogenation [4]. Lignin-derived syringol and guaiacol (GUA) are frequently used as model compounds in catalytic lignin studies. Syringol, with its two methoxy groups and one hydroxyl group, presents greater challenges in HDO compared to GUA due to steric hindrance and the need for multi-step demethoxylation [5,6]. Consequently, most prior research on lignin HDO has focused on GUA, with limited attention given to syringol. However, developing effective catalysts for syringol HDO is critical, as its conversion more accurately reflects the feasibility of transforming real lignin. Reported catalysts for the HDO of syringol include both noble metals and transition metals. Some noble metal catalysts exhibit catalytic activity at low temperatures (80–130 °C). However, they preferentially hydrogenate aromatic rings rather than cleaving methoxy groups (-OCH3). For example, syringol was completely converted over Ru/SBA-16 [7] after 4 h at 130 °C and 6 MPa H2, yielding 1,2,3-trimethoxycyclohexane as the main product (51.3 % selectivity). Similarly, Pd/SBA-16 [7] and Ru/SBA-15 [8] mainly produce saturated products with benzene rings. There are also catalysts with excessively high hydrogenation activity, not only saturating the aromatic ring but also cleaving both methoxy groups (-OCH3) and hydroxyl groups (-OH). For instance, a layered Ni1Co3Al2-600 catalyst [9] prepared by hydrothermal method achieved complete conversion of syringol with 90 % selectivity to cyclohexane (CYHA) after 4 h at 180 °C under 2 MPa H2. Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 [10] prepared by stepwise precipitation showed 98.4 % syringol conversion and 97.8 % CYHA selectivity after 2 h at 200 °C under 2 MPa H2. Furthermore, syringol HDO over Ru/HZSM-5 [11], Co/HZ-HT [12], CoNx@NC-650 [13], and NiMo@Al2O3@TiO2 [4] catalysts also demonstrates high selectivity toward either CYHA or methyl-substituted CYHA. A few catalysts can selectively cleave -OCH3 while preserving -OH during syringol HDO. For example, using a graphene-supported cobalt catalyst (Co/rGO), syringol achieved complete conversion with 93 % CYHAOL yield at 240 °C and 3.0 MPa H2 for 2 h [14]. The CoAg/SiO2 catalyst [15] and the Ru-MnOx/C catalyst [16] also selectively HDO of syringol to CYHAOL. Under hydrogen-lean conditions, the HDO of syringol may preserve the aromatic ring from hydrogenation. For instance, Luo et al. [17] achieved 95 % benzene yield from syringol HDO using Ru/HZSM-5 at 240 °C under 0.2 MPa H2 for 4 h, although the hydroxyl groups were also cleaved. The above studies indicate that the HDO of syringol to phenol remains challenging. The key lies in designing catalysts capable of selectively cleaving the -OCH3 group while preserving the -OH group and leaving the aromatic ring intact. Hydrogenation catalysts typically require pre-reduction treatment, which not only complicates catalyst preparation and maintenance procedures but also risks deactivation through oxidation during operation. To address this, Zhou's research group developed an innovative catalytic system where Ag additive drives in situ reduction and activication of the catalysts during reactions [15,18]. The Ag-promoted CoAg/SiO2 catalyst without pre-reduction treatment completely converts syringol under 260 °C and 3 MPa H2 in 2 h with 93.8 % CYHAOL selectivity, though with undesired aromatic ring hydrogenation. In another study, Zhou's group demonstrated that Fe incorporation into Co/rGO effectively suppresses aromatic ring hydrogenation. Their CoFe/rGO catalyst [19] achieved 94 % GUA conversion with 70.8 % phenol selectivity at 300 °C under 1 MPa H2 for 2 h. From both preparation and cost perspectives, SiO2 offers distinct advantages over reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as a support material. Therefore, this study proposes to modify our previously developed CoAg/SiO2 system with Fe promoters, aiming to develop an in-situ activated catalyst for syringol hydrogenation that simultaneously achieves high activity and phenol selectivity. We investigated the Co-Fe-Ag synergy and systematically evaluated the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst’s performance using batch reactions and characterizations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Taking CoFeAg/SiO2 as an example, Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China), Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (Tianjin Guangfu Fine Chemicals Research Institute Co., Ltd., China), and AgNO3 (Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) were used as donors of Co, Fe, and Ag, and the salt solution was loaded on SiO2 (Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China) by incipient wetness impregnation method. After impregnation, the catalyst precursors were dried at 80 °C for 12 h, ground and calcined in air at 500 °C for 2 h. To optimize the Co loading and clarify the roles of Fe or Ag promoters, catalysts with varying loadings of Co (0–3.5 mmol/g), Fe (0–0.5 mmol/g), and Ag (0–0.7 mmol/g) were designed and prepared. For comparison, single or bimetallic metals supported on SiO2, as well as CoFeAg supported on γ-Al2O3 (Shandong Filiale of China Aluminum Co., Ltd., China; pre-calcined at 500 °C in air), HY (SAR = 2.6, Wenzhou Huahua Co., Ltd., China), and activated carbon (AC, Lize Environmental Protection Technology Co., Ltd., Henan, China), were prepared using the same method. Except for CoFeAg/AC, which was calcined in N2, all other catalysts were calcined in air. All catalysts were used directly in the reaction without pre-reduction treatment. The catalysts in this study were denoted as CoxFeyAgz/Support, where x, y, and z represent the amounts (mmol) of Co, Fe, and Ag supported per gram of the support, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were acquired using a Tecnai G2 F30 microscope. Prior to analysis, the catalysts were dispersed in ethanol via sonication and deposited onto a copper grid. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on an ESCALAB-250 spectrometer using Al Kα X-rays (1486.6 eV). The peak position of Si 2p at 103.5 eV served as a reference for binding energy calibration, and spectra were processed using XPSPEAK 41 software. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX PLUS X-band spectrometer under the following conditions: 9.8 GHz microwave frequency, 20 mW power, 100 kHz modulation frequency, and 10 dB attenuator setting. Powder XRD patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Smart Lab diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) at 45 kV and 200 mA. Data were collected over a 2θ range of 10–90° with a step size of 0.01° using a spinning sample holder. Temperature-Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR), H2-Temperature-Programmed Desorption (H2-TPD), and NH3-Temperature-Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD) were conducted on an AutoChem II 2920 analyzer. H2 and NH3 concentrations were monitored by a TCD detector. For H2-TPR, samples (20 mg) were pretreated in Ar at 200 °C to remove adsorbed impurities, followed by reduction in 5 H2/Ar (40 mL/min) from 40 to 800 °C (5 °C/min). For H2-TPD, samples (30 mg) were first reduced in situ under 5 H2/Ar at 330 °C to mimic reaction conditions. After reduction, H2 adsorption was performed in the same gas mixture (40 mL/min) while cooling from 330 °C to 40 °C. Subsequently, H2 desorption was measured in an Ar flow (40 mL/min) by heating from 40 °C to 750 °C at 10 °C/min. For NH3-TPD, after drying 40 mg of catalyst in Ar at 300 °C, NH3 adsorption was performed at 100 °C until saturation. NH3 desorption was carried out in He flow (40 mL/min) from 100 to 750 °C (10 °C/min). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied in the linear range (P/P0 = 0.05–0.3) to determine the specific surface area (S BET). Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA) were analyzed on a TGA/SDTA851e instrument under a 30 mL/min gas flow, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic performance measurement The HDO reaction was performed in a 50 mL automated batch reactor (Beijing Century Senlang Experimental Apparatus Co., Ltd.). The typical reaction process was as follows. A mixture containing 500 mg syringol, 50 mg catalyst, 10 mL n-dodecane solvent, and 100 mg n-tetradecane (internal standard) was loaded into the reactor. After sealing and purging three times with H2, the system was pressurized to 1.0 MPa and heated to the target temperature for the prescribed reaction time. Upon completion, the reactor was quenched in an ice-water bath. To dissolve the product uniformly, 15 mL of ethyl acetate solution was added to the liquid-phase mixture. The products were filtered by needle filter, and analyzed by GC (Agilent 7820 with SE-30 capillary column and FID detector). Spent catalysts were washed with ethyl acetate, vacuum-dried, and stored in sealed vials for characterization or reuse. Syringol conversion (X), product yield (Yᵢ), and selectivity (Sᵢ) were calculated based on the C6 ring content using Eqs. (1)-(3): (1) X ( m o l % ) = n s y r i n g o l 0 − n s y r i n g o l t n s y r i n g o l 0 × 100 (2) S i ( m o l % ) = n i t n s y r i n g o l 0 − n s y r i n g o l t × 100 (3) Y i ( m o l % ) = n i t n s y r i n g o l 0 × 100 In the equations, n s y r i n g o l 0 and n s y r i n g o l t represent the molar amounts of syringol at the reaction times 0 and t, respectively, while n i t donates the molar amount of product i at t. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst In this study, the fresh catalyst was not pre-reduced but instead activated via in situ reduction within the reaction system. Thus, the composition and structural properties of the spent catalyst reflect its active state during the catalytic reaction. Accordingly, the characterization results of both the fresh and spent catalysts are analyzed and discussed together. 3.1.1 Electron microscope images Fig. 1 summarizes the morphologies of the fresh and spent Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalysts characterized by TEM and HRTEM. Fig. 1a and Fig. S1 reveals that the SiO2 support exhibit a uniform size distribution with an average diameter of 14 nm, while the Co, Fe, and Ag metals are highly dispersed on the SiO2 surface without forming distinct particles. The HRTEM image of the fresh Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst in Fig. 1b shows lattice fringes that, together with the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) pattern, can be indexed to the (311), (400), and (220) crystallographic planes of Co3O4 (JCPDS PDF No. 73–1701), confirming that the cobalt species in the fresh catalyst exists as Co3O4. No distinct lattice fringes corresponding to Fe or Ag were detected in the HRTEM image (Fig. 1b), and their elemental mapping images showed no agglomeration (Fig. 1c), confirming the high dispersion of Fe or Ag and effective doping within the Co matrix. Fig. 1d reveals that no significant aggregation of metal particles occurs in the spent Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst after the reaction. The HRTEM image and FFT pattern of the spent catalyst (Fig. 1e) displays lattice fringes corresponding to Co (111) (JCPDS PDF Card No.: 15–0806) and CoO (200) (JCPDS PDF Card No.: 89–7099). These observations indicate that the initial single-phase Co3O4 in the fresh catalyst undergoes in situ reduction during the reaction, transforming into a polycrystalline structure composed of metallic Co and CoO. The mechanism by which Ag promotes the reduction of metal oxides can be rationalized as follows [18,20]. First, the electron transfer effect plays a key role, where Ag acts as an electron sink or trap medium. Through interfacial electron interactions (e.g., electron donation from Ag to the oxide), Ag modifies the electronic state of the oxide, thereby lowering the reduction energy barrier. The other is the hydrogen spillover effect. Metallic Ag activates H₂ and serves as a hydrogen spillover mediator, facilitating hydrogen migration to the oxide surface and thus reducing the required reduction temperature. 3.1.2 XPS and EPR Fig. 2 presents the XPS spectra of fresh and spent Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalysts. In the fresh catalyst, the Co 2p spectra exhibit binding energies at 780.5 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 795.8 eV (Co 2p1/2), along with faint satellite peaks, confirming the presence of Co3O4 [21]. After the reaction, the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks shift to 781.6 eV and 797.4 eV, respectively, accompanied by two prominent satellite peaks at 785.9 eV and 803 eV, showing evident characteristic of CoO [15]. Additionally, two weak peaks at 778 eV and 793 eV indicate the formation of metallic Co in the spent catalyst [14]. These XPS results demonstrate that Co3O4 undergoes in situ reduction during the reaction, transforming into CoO and metallic Co complex, which is consistent with the HRTEM findings. Fig. 2b displays the Fe 2p XPS spectra of the fresh and spent catalysts. In the fresh catalyst, the peaks at 712.0 eV (Fe 2p3/2) and 718.8 eV (satellite peak) correspond to Fe3+ [22]. After the reaction, the binding energy of Fe increases, indicating electron donation by Fe species during the in situ reduction process [23]. Moreover, the 2p₃/₂ main peak of Fe³ ⁺ decreased significantly in the spent sample in the XPS analysis. To enhance the signal, we performed Fe 2p XPS analysis on the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1Ox catalyst prepared by the co-precipitation method. As shown in Fig. S2, compared to the fresh Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1Ox catalyst, the spent catalyst also exhibited a significant decrease in the 2p₃/₂ main peak of the Fe³ ⁺ signal. Bagus et al. [24] studied the covalent character of the interaction between the metal cation and the oxygen ligands in iron oxides. They found that changes in covalency for the ions are responsible for significant variations in relaxation energies in XPS spectra, as well as the intensity loss from the main XPS peaks to shake-up satellites. The oxygen vacancies in the spent Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst increased significantly. Surface effects and defects (such as oxygen vacancies) in the catalyst material may lead to a redistribution of ligand electrons, further promoting ligand-to-metal charge transfer and the weakening of the 2p₃/₂ main peak. This suggests that Fe provides an electronic effect to facilitate the catalytic activation. XPS analysis of Ag ( Fig. 2 c) showed coexisting Ag 0 and Ag + in the fresh catalyst, with Ag 0 exhibiting characteristic spin-orbit doublets at 368.4 eV (3d 5/2 ) and 374.4 eV (3d 3/2 ), while weaker Ag + signals (368.1 eV and 374.1 eV) [25] indicated Ag 0 as the dominant species. In the spent catalyst, the complete disappearance of Ag + peaks and exclusive retention of Ag 0 signals confirmed the full reduction of Ag + to Ag 0 during the reaction. Fig. 2d reveals the O 1 s spectra of the catalysts, where the O signals from metal oxides are suppressed due to interference from SiO2. To address this, we prepared co-precipitated catalyst with identical Co/Fe/Ag molar ratios (Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1Ox) for dedicated O 1 s analysis. As shown in Fig. 2e, the peaks at 529.7 eV, 531.4 eV, and 533 eV correspond to lattice oxygen in cobalt oxides, oxygen near vacancies, and adsorbed oxygen species, respectively [26,27]. After reaction, the lattice oxygen content decreases while oxygen vacancy-related peaks intensify, indicating that the reduction of Co3O4 to a CoO-Co composite generates additional oxygen vacancies. Comparative EPR analysis of Co2.5/SiO2 and Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 (Fig. 2f) confirms that Fe and Ag incorporation significantly enhances oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst system [28]. 3.1.3 TPR, TPD and XRD The reduction characteristics and intermetallic coordination effects in the catalyst system were systematically investigated through H2-TPR (Fig. 3a), H2-TPD ( Fig. 3b), NH3-TPD (Fig. 3c), and XRD (Fig. 3d) analyses. As shown in Fig. 3a, the Fe0.1/SiO2 and Ag0.1/SiO2 catalysts exhibited negligible reduction features, likely due to their ultralow metal loadings. In contrast, the Co2.5/SiO2 catalyst displayed two distinct reduction maxima at 370 °C and 410 °C, corresponding to the sequential reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (Co3O4 → CoO) and Co2+ to Co0 (CoO → metallic Co) [29]. Notably, introducing trace Ag into Co2.5/SiO2 (Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2) induced a significant downward shift in both reduction peaks. Conversely, Fe incorporation in Co2.5Fe0.1/SiO2 caused a two-tier shift: a low-temperature shift for the Co3+ → Co2+ reduction and a high-temperature shift for the Co2+ → Co0 reduction, accompanied by pronounced peak broadening in the high-temperature region. The trimetallic Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst balanced the effects of Ag and Fe promoters, exhibiting a low-temperature Co3+ → Co2+ reduction peak at 240 °C and a broad high-temperature Co2+ → Co0 reduction feature spanning 300–430 °C. The prepared Co-based catalysts were calcined at 500 °C in air prior to the reaction. In the reaction system (under 1 MPa H2 at 330 °C), Co 3 O 4 in the catalysts is first reduced in situ to form the active phase before participating in catalysis. Fig. 3e predicts the states of Co species in the different catalysts. Based on the reduction profiles in Fig. 3a, we deduce that Co 2.5 /SiO 2 remains largely unreduced under these conditions, with Co predominantly existing as Co 3 O 4 . In contrast, Co 2.5 Ag 0.1 /SiO 2 undergoes complete reduction of Co 3+ to Co 2+ (Co 3 O 4 → CoO), followed by further reduction of most Co 2+ to Co 0 (CoO → metallic Co). For the Co 2.5 Fe 0.1 Ag 0.1 /SiO 2 catalyst, Co 3+ is fully reduced to Co 2+ (Co 3 O 4 → CoO), but due to the presence of Fe, the subsequent reduction of CoO to Co is hindered, resulting in a highly doped CoO-Co structure. This is corroborated by XRD (Fig. 3d), where the Co 3 O 4 diffraction peaks in the fresh Co 2.5 Fe 0.1 Ag 0.1 /SiO 2 catalyst disappear after reaction, replaced by weak CoO and Co signals, indicating ultrasmall and highly dispersed CoO-Co crystallites—consistent with HRTEM observations (Fig. 1e). It was reported that CoO-Co doping generates abundant oxygen vacancies (O ᴠ ) [30–33], further supported by O 1 s XPS and EPR (Fig. 2), confirming their high concentration in this catalyst. Fig. 3b presents the H2-TPD results of the catalysts, which were pre-reduced with H2 at 330 °C to simulate in situ reduction in the reaction system before H2 adsorption. A lower H2 desorption temperature indicates higher hydrogenation activity. Both Ag0.1/SiO2 and Fe0.1/SiO2 exhibit higher H2 desorption peaks, suggesting weaker hydrogenation capability. In contrast, Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 and Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2 show two distinct desorption peaks, indicating the presence of two types of hydrogenation active sites. While their medium-temperature desorption peaks at 300 °C are similar in area, Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 demonstrates a significantly larger low-temperature desorption peak at 200 °C compared to Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2, implying a greater number of highly active hydrogenation sites in the former [34,35]. Combined with H2-TPR analysis, the introduction of Fe promotes the formation of highly dispersed CoO-Co crystallites with abundant Oᴠ, which construct numerous high-activity hydrogenation sites. Additionally, Fig. 3c reveals that the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst not only retains the weak acid sites from the SiO2 support but also possesses strong acid centers derived from the loaded Co, Fe, and Ag components. These strong acid sites primarily originate from Oᴠ and metal oxides, such as CoO [36,37]. 3.1.4 N2 adsorption/desorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis provides insight into the specific surface area and pore structure characteristics of the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst and its support (SiO2). As shown in Fig. 4a, the SiO2 support exhibits typical type IV isotherm feature with H1-type hysteresis loop, indicating a uniform mesoporous structure. Specifically, the specific surface area of SiO2 is 216 m2∙g−1. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the calcined Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst were very similar to those of the SiO2 support, which indicates that the support's skeletal structure was maintained without significant changes during the catalyst preparation. The specific surface area of the catalyst decreased slightly to 172 m2∙g−1. Fig. 4b shows that as the Co loading increases, the specific surface area of the catalyst gradually decreases. Similarly, increasing the Fe and Ag contents also result in slow declines in specific surface areas. This is because the proportion of metals increases, leading to a reduction in the content of the SiO2 support per gram of catalyst. 3.2 Comparison of CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst with the others The catalytic performance of CoFeAg/SiO2 catalysts in the HDO of syringol is presented in Table 1. For comparison, the reaction results of catalysts with different metals and supports are also listed. All catalysts were used without pre-reduction treatment. Prior to the reaction, the catalysts were activated in situ at 330 °C under 1.0 MPa H2 in the reaction system, after which they exhibited catalytic activity. In this reaction, "Others" primarily consisted of methyl-transfer products of syringol. Notably, even when using pure SiO2 as the catalyst, 37.2 mol% of syringol underwent methyl transfer (Table 1, Entry 1). Data in Entry 2 of Table 1 shows that Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 achieved 100 mol% conversion of syringol with 52.4 mol% phenol selectivity. Besides, most of the byproducts retained the aromatic ring including GUA ( 1.5 mol%), anisole (9.4 mol%), cresols (12.3 mol%), and catechol (1.0 mol%). The selectivity for aromatic ring hydrogenation byproducts (S Arly-hydrogenation) accounted for 15.9 mol% [the sum of the selectivity of CYHAOL, cyclohexanone (CYHO), cyclohexene (CYHE), and CYHA]. The Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated the ability to cleave the -OCH3 groups of syringol while minimizing hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, achieving a high phenol yield of 52.4 mol%. Such performance has rarely been reported in previous studies. Table S1 summarizes the results of syringol hydrogenation reactions from the literature. It can be seen that Ru/SBA-16 and Pd/SBA-16 [7] only hydrogenated the aromatic ring. Catalysts such as Ru/SBA-15 [8], Ni1Co3Al2-600 [9], Co/rGO [14], CoAg/SiO2 [15], and Ru–MnOx/C [16] were capable of cleaving -OCH3 but also hydrogenated the aromatic ring, primarily yielding alcohols. Meanwhile, Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 [10], Ru/HZSM-5 [11], Co/HZ-HT [12], CoNx@NC-650 [13], and NiMo@Al2O3@TiO2 [4] not only cleaved -OCH3 and hydrogenated the aromatic ring but also dissociated the -OH groups of syringol, resulting in CYHA as the main product. The Ru/HZSM-5 [17] catalyst exhibited unique behavior, cleaving all oxygen-containing functional groups of syringol while protecting the aromatic ring from hydrogenation, selectively producing benzene. Only our CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst selectively cleaved the -OCH3 groups of syringol, preserved the -OH group, and minimized aromatic ring hydrogenation, achieving high selectivity for phenolic products. The catalytic activity of Fe0.1/SiO2 and Ag0.1/SiO2 is similar to that of the support, resulting in a relatively low syringol conversion. However, in addition to catalyzing methyl transfer, these two catalysts can also cleave -OCH3. Due to their weak hydrogenation capability, they do not hydrogenate the benzene ring. According to the H2-TPR results in Fig. 3a, it can be deduced that without the promoting effect of Ag, Co2.5/SiO2 and Co2.5Fe0.1/SiO2 were difficult to undergo effective in-situ reduction and activation in the 330 °C reaction system, leading to their low catalytic activity. In contrast, Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2 exhibits high catalytic activity, achieving complete conversion of syringol. However, its phenol selectivity is 11.2 mol% lower than that of Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2, while the selectivity for benzene ring hydrogenation byproducts is 11.5 mol% higher. Based on the H2-TPR analysis results in Fig. 3a, it can be inferred that the in-situ reduction degree of Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2 in the reaction system is stronger than that of Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2, generating a large amount of metallic Co, which enhances benzene ring hydrogenation. This suggests that Fe modulates the appropriate reduction of the Co component in the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst, constructing a structure of CoO-Co polycrystals with abundant Ov sites, thereby enabling highly selective phenol production. Three inorganic supports (SiO₂, HY zeolite, and γ-Al₂O₃) and an organic carbon material (AC) were used for supporting metals. Since the prepared catalysts were not pre-reduced and relied on Ag-promoted in situ reduction to achieve catalytic activity, the selected supports were required not only to anchor and disperse metal species but also to preserve the promotional role of Ag. The chemical properties of the three types of inorganic supports primarily reflected in the following three aspects: HY zeolite and γ-Al₂O₃ are highly polar, while SiO₂ is less polar; HY contains the strongest acidity, γ-Al₂O₃ exhibits moderate acidity, and SiO₂ shows only weak acidity; γ-Al₂O₃ and HY provide strong anchoring for Co oxides, whereas SiO₂ offers weaker interactions. For Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/Al2O3 and Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/HY, the strong anchoring of Co₃O₄ on the HY and Al₂O₃ surfaces limits Ag's ability to promote reduction, as shown in Fig. 5. As a consequence, the reactions over the two catalysts are primarily driven by the acidic sites of the supports, leading to methyl transfer reactions. The H2-TPR profile of Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/AC in Fig. 5 exhibits a very small reduction peak. This is because, during calcination at 500 °C under nitrogen flow, a significant portion of the Co species is reduced to metallic Co by carbothermal reduction, as evidenced by XRD pattern in Fig. S3. Similar to Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2, the abundance of metallic Co in this catalyst triggers benzene ring hydrogenation, resulting in lower phenol selectivity. The strong hydrogenation activity of Ni in Ni2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 leads to the selective formation of 41.8 mol% benzene-ring hydrogenated products. In contrast, Cu exhibits excessively weak hydrogenation activity, causing Cu2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 to achieve only a 40.7 mol% conversion of syringol. Thus, the Co component, with its moderate hydrogenation activity, supported on the weakly acidic SiO2, achieves optimal catalytic performance under the synergistic regulation of Fe and Ag. This balance ensures high conversion while maintaining desirable phenol product selectivity. 3.3 Effect of catalyst preparation conditions Fig. 6 demonstrates the effects of metal loadings and calcination temperatures on the performance of CoFeAg/SiO2. As shown in Fig. 6a, the conversion of syringol gradually increased with higher Co loading, reaching complete conversion at 2.0 mmol/g. Meanwhile, phenol selectivity first increased and then decreased with increasing Co content, peaking at 2.5 mmol/g. Increasing the Fe loading (Fig. 6b) suppressed catalytic activity. When Fe reached 0.2 mmol/g, syringol could no longer be fully converted, and excessive Fe further reduced phenol selectivity. Based on catalytic performance and selectivity, an optimal Fe loading of 0.1 mmol/g was determined. Without Ag, syringol conversion was only 38.7 mol% (Fig. 6c). However, upon adding 0.05 mmol/g Ag, conversion surged to 97.1 mol%, highlighting Ag’s crucial role in activating the catalyst. Phenol selectivity peaked at 52.4 mol% with 0.1 mmol/g Ag, beyond which further increases had negligible effects. Considering these results, the optimal loadings for Co, Fe, and Ag on SiO2 were determined to be 2.5, 0.1, and 0.1 mmol/g, respectively. Fig. 6d presents the XRD patterns of catalysts with the highest metal loadings. More detailed XRD data under varying preparation conditions are provided in Fig. S4. The fresh catalysts exhibited diffraction peaks primarily attributed to Co3O4, while no distinct signals for Fe or Ag species were detected, even at their highest loadings. With increasing Co loading, the diffraction peaks of Co3O4 intensify, indicating that excessive Co reduces dispersion. Despite the excellent dispersion of Ag and Fe, the reaction results revealed that excessive Ag loading had limited effects on enhancing catalytic performance, while excessive Fe loading even suppressed catalytic activity. From a series of characterizations, it was demonstrated that Ag, as a promoter, facilitates the reduction of Co oxides, whereas Fe, as another promoter, inhibits the excessive reduction of CoO to Co. The proper synergistic effect between Ag/Fe and Co oxides helps construct more CoO-Co-Ov active sites, thereby promoting the hydrogenolysis of the CAryl—O bonds. Fig. 6e demonstrates the effect of calcination temperature on the performance of the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst. The catalyst calcined at 300 °C shows incomplete syringol conversion, while those calcined between 400 and 600 °C achieve complete conversion. At 700 °C, a marginal decrease to 99 % conversion is observed. Phenol selectivity follows a volcano-shaped trend with increasing calcination temperature. The inferior performance at lower temperatures (<400 °C) originates from incomplete decomposition of metal nitrate precursors into active oxides [19]. XRD analysis reveals that temperatures ≥ 600 °C promote Co3O4 crystallite growth through particle agglomeration, correlating with the slight activity decline. Considering both catalytic performance and structural stability, 500 °C emerges as the optimal calcination temperature for this catalyst system. 3.4 Effects of reaction conditions The HDO of syringol over the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst (calcined at 500 °C) was systematically optimized, with a focus on evaluating the effects of reaction temperature, time, and hydrogen pressure on catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 7a, the reaction temperature significantly influenced both the conversion of syringol and the product distribution. Increasing the temperature from 280 °C to 310 °C led to a rise in syringol conversion, achieving complete conversion at 310 °C. At the lower temperature of 280 °C, CYHAOL was the dominant product (with a selectivity of 27 mol%), while phenol selectivity was only 20 mol%. However, as the temperature increased, hydrogenation of the aromatic ring was suppressed, resulting in a significant increase in the selectivity toward phenolic products (phenol and cresols). Specifically, phenol selectivity reached a maximum of 52.4 mol% at 330 °C, while CYHAOL selectivity decreased to 3.7 mol% accordingly. When the temperature exceeded 330 °C, phenol selectivity plateaued, but the selectivities of anisole and cresols showed a gradual increase. At 350 °C, the combined selectivity of aromatic ring-retained products reached 91.9 mol%. These findings demonstrate that higher temperatures favor the formation of products with retained aromatic rings in the HDO of syringol. Shi et al. [38] systematically studied the effect of reaction temperature on phenol hydrogenation over Ni catalysts and found that phenyl group adsorption was significantly suppressed at 320–400 °C, while hydroxyl adsorption persisted even at high temperatures (350–400 °C). This temperature-dependent adsorption behavior dictates the reaction selectivity: the hydrogenation of the phenyl ring is more inhibited at elevated temperatures due to weakened benzene ring adsorption compared to oxygen-containing functional groups, thereby favoring CAryl-O bond hydrogenolysis over aromatic ring hydrogenation and resulting in high selectivity toward phenolic products at high temperatures. As shown in Fig. 7b, when the reaction temperature was fixed at 330 °C, syringol conversion increased with prolonged reaction time, reaching complete conversion after 4 h. In the early stages of the reaction, GUA and catechol were observed as notable byproducts, but their selectivities gradually decreased as the reaction progressed. Meanwhile, the selectivities of phenol, cresols, and anisole increased over time. Phenol selectivity initially rose with extended reaction time but experienced a slight decline after 4 h, accompanied by a minor increase in CYHAOL selectivity. These trends in product distribution closely relate to the sequential reaction pathway. Hydrogen pressure experiments (Fig. 7c) revealed that both excessively high and low hydrogen pressures negatively affected phenol selectivity. Under high-pressure conditions (1.5–2.0 MPa), hydrogenation of the benzene ring became more pronounced, leading to a sharp drop in phenol selectivity and the formation of significant amounts of CYHA. The optimal catalytic performance was achieved at a hydrogen pressure of 1.0 MPa. Besides, in the initial stage of the reaction, a considerable amount of methyl transfer byproducts (labeled as "Others") are generated. As shown in Fig. 7, these "Others" products gradually decrease with reaction progression while being converted into various hydrogenation products. This observation demonstrates that the methyl transfer reaction does not significantly affect the final selectivity of target products. 3.5 Stability test of catalyst The stability of the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst in the syringol reaction was evaluated, and the results were presented in Fig. S5. The spent catalyst was directly reused for the recycling test (Cycle 1) after centrifugal recovery. As shown in Fig. S5a, the recycled catalyst exhibited the reduced activity compared to the fresh catalyst, confirming its deactivation during the catalytic process. Generally, the causes of hydrogenation catalyst deactivation include sintering [39,40], oxidative deactivation [41,42], and carbon deposition [10,43]. TEM analysis in Fig. 1 revealed that sintering of the catalyst was negligible after the reaction. This can be attributed to the fact that the active Co component exists as a CoO-Co composite, where the oxidized state enhances strong interaction with the support, preventing sintering. Additionally, since the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst is activated via in situ reduction in the reaction system by Ag promotion, oxidative deactivation is unlikely. Fig. S5b presents the TG analysis of fresh and spent Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalysts. The weight loss observed in the spent catalyst between 350–600 °C confirms carbon deposition during the reaction. When the spent catalyst was regenerated by calcination at 500 °C in air to remove coke, its catalytic activity was restored to 96 % of its original level. 3.6 Proposed reaction pathways and catalytic mechanisms 3.6.1 Reaction pathways The product distribution of the HDO reaction of syringol varies with reaction time (Fig. S6), which can be used to deduce the reaction pathways. To assist in the analysis, probe reactions were conducted using GUA, phenol, catechol, CYHAOL, CYHO, CYHA, and methanol as raw materials over the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst ( Table 2). Fig. S6 shows that phenol, GUA, and catechol were detected in the early stages of the reaction, suggesting that these products may be directly derived from syringol. GUA and catechol can undergo further conversion to phenol, as evidenced by the gradual decline in their selectivity over time, accompanied by a corresponding increase in phenol selectivity. Further hydrogenation of phenol can form CYHAOL, CYHO, CYHE, and CYHA. Based on the probe reaction using GUA as a feedstock (Table 2, Entry 2), it is inferred that GUA can not only produce phenol but also dissociate its -OH group to form anisole or undergo methyl transfer and -OH dissociation to yield cresols. In the probe reaction with CYHAOL as the feedstock, CYHO was detected, and conversely, CYHAOL was observed when CYHO was used as the feedstock, indicating that these two compounds can interconvert. No decomposition products of CYHA were detected after a prolonged 10-hour reaction, confirming that the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst does not catalyze the ring-opening reaction. Theoretically, if the methoxy group of syringol is removed as CH3OH (cleavage of CAryl—OCH3 bond), the reaction would produce 2 moles of methanol for every 1 mol of phenol generated. In the reactions catalyzed by Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 using syringol and guaiacol as feedstocks, methanol was detected in the products. This suggests that the removal of the methoxy group from syringol may occur through direct cleavage of the CAryl—OCH3 bond, releasing methanol as a primary product. However, the measured methanol content in the products was much lower than the stoichiometric ratio predicted. For example, in a representative reaction (Table 2, Entry 1), the molar ratio of methanol to phenol was only 1:10. To further investigate this discrepancy, a model reaction using methanol as the feedstock was conducted (Table 2, Entry 8). The results revealed that methanol readily decomposes into methane over the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst，and the amount converted aligns with the methane content detected in the gaseous product. Therefore, it is plausible that the methanol generated from the demethoxylation of syringol undergoes further conversion to methane. The NH3-TPD results (Fig. 3c) reveal that the Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst retains the weak acid sites of the SiO2 support while also exhibiting strong acid centers introduced by the loaded metal components. The methyl transfer reaction (transalkylation) from the methoxy group to the phenolic ring depends on the catalyst’s acidic functionality [44]. Meanwhile, CAryl–OH bond cleavage (dehydroxylation) proceeds more readily over bifunctional metal-acid catalysts [44,45]. When pure SiO2 was used as the catalyst, 37.2 mol% of syringol underwent methyl transfer (Table 1, Entry 1). The probe reactions with phenol and catechol as the feedstocks confirmed that Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 effectively cleaves hydroxyl groups (Table 2, Entries 3 and 4). Thus, we propose an alternative pathway for methoxy group removal in syringol through methyl transfer (transalkylation) followed by CAryl–OH bond cleavage (dehydroxylation). Regardless of the reaction pathway for methoxy group removal, methane formation should be observed evidently. Indeed, significant methane presented in gaseous byproduct during the HDO of syringol. The probe reaction using CYHA as the feedstock (Table 2, Entry 7) confirmed that Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 does not catalyze ring-opening reactions under the given conditions. Therefore, the detected methane originates from syringol’s methoxy groups. Based on the above analysis, the reaction pathway illustrated in Scheme 1 was proposed. 3.6.2 Catalytic mechanisms The excellent catalytic performance of the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst is closely related to its selective adsorption of syringol at oxygen-containing functional groups, as well as the hydrogen dissociation property. The aforementioned pathways (Scheme 1) involve CAryl—O bond hydrogenolysis and aromatic ring hydrogenation, both of which require the adsorption of the reactive sites of syringol onto the catalytic active centers. Polycrystalline CoO-Co can generate abundant oxygen vacancies, which preferentially adsorb and activate the oxygen-containing functional groups over the aromatic ring. During the in-situ reduction of the CoAg/SiO2 catalyst under reaction conditions, Ag promotes excessive reduction of Co3O4, leading to an abundance of metallic Co sites but insufficient CoO-Co-Ov sites. In contrast, in the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst, Fe inhibits the excessive reduction of CoO to Co, allowing Ag and Fe to cooperatively regulate the reduction degree of Co3O4 and generate a high density of CoO-Co-Ov active sites. This adsorption-dependent reaction mechanism affects the reaction selectivity: Oxygen-containing functional groups are more favorably adsorbed on CoFeAg/SiO2, thereby promoting CAryl—O bond hydrogenolysis rather than aromatic ring hydrogenation and resulting in high selectivity toward phenolic products. The HDO of syringol to phenol involves the cleavage of the CAryl—O bonds. Initially, the oxygen-containing functional group adsorbs onto an Ov site, leading to the weakening and activation of the CAryl—O bond, which is subsequently cleaved via hydrogenation. It is reported that the Hδ+ − Hδ− pair derived from the heterolytic dissociation of H2 is more favorable for C−O bond cleavage [46]. The heterolytic cleavage of H2 can occur on the metal oxides with oxygen vacancies, which play an important role in the formation and stabilisation of Hδ− species [33,44]. Xiang et al. [33] reported a unique core-shell structured catalyst, Co@CoO for hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran. The Co@CoO catalyst was prepared by partial reduction of the Co3O4 powder, constructing a core-shell structure with a Co metal core and a CoO shell containing oxygen vacancies. The computational modeling and various spectroscopic experiments revealed that the CoO shell incorporating oxygen vacancies can drive the heterolytic cleavages of H2, leading to exceptional catalytic activity in the HDO of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. As indicated by previous characterization results, the Co component in the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst exists in the form of CoO-Co polycrystals with abundant Ov, which facilitates the heterolytic cleavage of H2. In contrast, on metallic Co sites, H2 tends to undergo homolytic dissociation. Fig. 8 demonstrates the catalytic functionality of the as-fabricated components of the CoFeAg/SiO2. Therefore, in the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst, Ag facilitates the in-situ reduction of Co₃O₄, while Fe suppresses the over-reduction of CoO to metallic Co. Under this dual modulation by Fe and Ag, the catalyst forms abundant CoO-Co-Ov sites, which selectively adsorb oxygen-containing functional groups and promote heterolytic H₂ cleavage. This mechanism drives the efficient scission of CAryl—O bonds, enabling the highly selective conversion of syringol to phenol. 4 Conclusion The catalytic HDO of lignin-derived syringol to phenol presents a promising route for sustainable phenol production. However, this process remains challenging due to the difficulty in selectively cleaving CAryl–O bonds while preserving the aromatic ring and a phenolic –OH group. This study successfully developed a trimetallic CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst that achieves high activity and selectivity in the HDO of syringol to phenol, overcoming the limitations of monometallic and bimetallic counterparts. As promoters, Ag facilitates the low-temperature reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and further to metallic Co, while Fe prevents excessive reduction of CoO to Co, balancing CoO and metallic Co phases and increasing Oᴠ concentration. Through the synergistic effects of Fe and Ag on Co, the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst undergoes in situ reduction under reaction conditions (1 MPa H2, 330 °C), forming a polycrystalline CoO-Co structure with abundant Oᴠ and Lewis acid sites. Unlike metallic Co-dominated active sites, the CoO-Co-Oᴠ structure enables heterolytic H2 cleavage while preferentially adsorbs and activates the oxygen-containing functional groups over the aromatic ring. This dual role selectively promotes CAryl–O bond dissociation while suppressing undesired ring hydrogenation. The Co2.5Fe0.1Ag0.1/SiO2 catalyst achieves 100 % syringol conversion with 52.4 mol% phenol selectivity—significantly outperforming the bimetallic Co2.5Ag0.1/SiO2 (41.2 mol% phenol selectivity) and monometallic Co2.5/SiO2 (7.6 mol% phenol selectivity). This work provides a catalyst design strategy for sustainable phenol production from renewable biomass resources. coredata.dc:description: The hydrodeoxygenation of lignin-derived syringol to phenol faces challenges in selectively cleaving CAryl–O bonds while maintaining aromatic ring and a phenolic -OH group integrity. Herein, we developed a trimetallic CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst that achieves 100 % syringol conversion and 52.4 % phenol selectivity, surpassing bimetallic CoAg/SiO2 (42.2 mol%) and monometallic Co/SiO2 (7.6 mol%) catalysts. As promoters, Ag facilitates the low-temperature reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and further to metallic Co, while Fe prevents excessive reduction of CoO to metallic Co. Through the synergistic effects of Fe and Ag on Co, the CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst undergoes in situ reduction under reaction conditions (1 MPa H2, 330 °C), forming a polycrystalline CoO-Co structure with abundant oxygen vacancy (Oᴠ) and Lewis acid sites. The CoO-Co-Ov active sites facilitate heterolytic H2 cleavage while preferentially adsorbing and activating oxygen-containing functional groups over the aromatic ring of syringol. This dual functionality selectively promotes CAryl–O bond dissociation while suppressing undesired ring hydrogenation, providing an effective catalyst design strategy for sustainable phenol production from biomass-derived syringol.

coredata.dc:title: Fe-mediated enhancement of phenol selectivity in syringol hydrodeoxygenation over an in-situ-activated CoFeAg/SiO2 catalyst
